trans-unit.source: Gets formatting information for text, given a wrap limit.
Gets how long the particle system will emit particles
Gets how long the particle system will emit particles (if -1 then it emits particles forever).
Gets information about an 'extern' ('uniform') variable in the Shader.
Gets information about an 'extern' ('uniform') variable in the shader.
Gets information about the system's power supply.
Gets information about the system's video card and drivers.
Gets performance-related rendering statistics.
Gets reference texture dimensions initially specified in love.graphics.newQuad.
Gets text from the clipboard.
Gets the blending mode.
Gets the bodies that the Joint is attached to.
Gets the Data's size in bytes.
Gets the FileMode the file has been opened with.
Gets the filter mode of the Canvas.
Gets the filter mode of the Canvas.
Gets the Font used with the Text object.
Gets the Font used with the Text object.
Gets the Image used when drawing the Mesh.
Gets the point size.
Gets the VideoStream object used for decoding and controlling the video.
Gets the World the body lives in.
Gets the Data's size in bytes.
Gets the Angular damping of the Body
Gets the Angular damping of the Body.
Gets the DPI scale factor associated with the window.
Gets the Source's directional volume cones.
Gets the Source's directional volume cones. Together with Source:setDirection, the cone angles allow for the Source's volume to vary depending on its direction.
Gets the absolute path of the directory containing a filepath.
Gets the active color components used when drawing.
Gets the active color components used when drawing. Normally all 4 components are active unless love.graphics.setColorMask has been used.
Gets the amount of directional spread of the particle emitter (in radians).
Gets the amount of linear damping (constant deceleration) for particles.
Gets the amount of particles emitted per second.
Gets the amount of particles that are currently in the system.
Gets the amount of size variation (0 meaning no variation and 1 meaning full variation between start and end).
Gets the amount of size variation.
Gets the amount of spin variation (0 meaning no variation and 1 meaning full variation between start and end).
Gets the amount of spin variation.
Gets the area-based spawn parameters for the particles.
Gets the ascent of the Font in pixels.
Gets the ascent of the Font. The ascent spans the distance between the baseline and the top of the glyph that reaches farthest from the baseline.
Gets the audio Source used for playing back the video's audio.
Gets the audio Source used for playing back the video's audio. May return nil if the video has no audio, or if Video:setSource is called with a nil argument.
Gets the available Canvas formats, and whether each is supported.
Gets the available compressed image formats, and whether each is supported.
Gets the baseline of the Font in pixels.
Gets the baseline of the Font. Most scripts share the notion of a baseline: an imaginary horizontal line on which characters rest. In some scripts, parts of glyphs lie below the baseline.
Gets the blending mode.
Gets the bounding box of the shape.
Gets the bounding box of the shape. This function can be used in a nested fashion with love.graphics.polygon.
Gets the buffer mode of a file.
Gets the button, axis or hat that a virtual gamepad input is bound to.
Gets the categories as a 16-bit integer.
Gets the categories as a 16-bit integer. A set bit indicates membership of that category.
Gets the categories this shape is a member of.
Gets the categories this shape is a member of. The number of categories the shape is a member of is the number of return values. Categories are used for allowing/disallowing certain collision.
Gets the center point of the circle shape.
Gets the child indices of the shapes of the two colliding fixtures.
Gets the child indices of the shapes of the two colliding fixtures. For ChainShapes, an index of 1 is the first edge in the chain.
Gets the color mode (which controls how images are affected by the current color).
Gets the color of a pixel at a specific position in the image.
Gets the color of a pixel.
Gets the color that will be used for the next add and set operations.
Gets the colors to apply to the particle sprite.
Gets the compression format of the CompressedData.
Gets the current point style.
Gets the current Shader.
Gets the current Shader. Returns nil if none is set.
Gets the current Cursor.
Gets the current Font object.
Gets the current background color.
Gets the current color.
Gets the current global scale factor for velocity-based doppler effects.
Gets the current line stipple.
Gets the current line width.
Gets the current number of simultaneously playing sources.
Gets the current operating system.

Gets the current operating system. In general, LÖVE abstracts away the need to know the current operating system, but there are a few cases where it can be useful (especially in combination with os.execute.)
Gets the current pitch of the Source.
Gets the current playback position of the Video.
Gets the current point style.
Gets the current position of the specified touch-press, in pixels.
Gets the current position of the specified touch-press.
Gets the current pressure of the specified touch-press.
Gets the current running version of LÖVE.
Gets the current scissor box.
Gets the current state of the random number generator.
Gets the current state of the random number generator. This returns an opaque implementation-dependent string which is only useful for later use with RandomGenerator:setState.
Gets the current stencil test configuration.
Gets the current target Canvas.
Gets the current vibration motor strengths on a Joystick with rumble support.
Gets the current viewport of this Quad.
Gets the current volume of the Source.
Gets the current working directory.
Gets the currently playing position of the Source.
Gets the damping ratio.
Gets the density of the Shape.
Gets the descent of the Font in pixels.
Gets the descent of the Font. The descent spans the distance between the baseline and the lowest descending glyph in a typeface.
Gets the direction of a hat.
Gets the direction of a virtual gamepad axis.
Gets the direction of a virtual gamepad axis. If the Joystick isn't recognized as a gamepad or isn't connected, this function will always return 0.
Gets the direction of an axis.
Gets the direction of each axis.
Gets the direction of the Joystick's hat.
Gets the direction of the Source.
Gets the direction of the particle emitter (in radians).
Gets the display mode and properties of the window.
Gets the duration of the Source.
Gets the duration of the Source. For streaming Sources it may not always be sample-accurate, and may return -1 if the duration cannot be determined at all.
Gets the duration of the sound data.
Gets the duration of the sound file.
Gets the duration of the sound file. It may not always be sample-accurate, and it may return -1 if the duration cannot be determined at all.
Gets the equilibrium distance between the two Bodies.
Gets the extension of the FileData.
Gets the filename of the FileData.
Gets the filename that the File object was created with.
Gets the filename that the File object was created with. If the file object originated from the love.filedropped callback, the filename will be the full platform-dependent file path.
Gets the filesystem paths that will be searched when require is called.
Gets the filter data of the Shape.
Gets the filter mode for a font.
Gets the filter mode for an image.
Gets the flags used when the image was created.
Gets the flags used when the image was created.
Gets the format of the CompressedImageData.
Gets the friction of this shape.
Gets the full Data as a string.
Gets the full Data as a string.
Gets the full ImageData as a string.
Gets the full path to the designated save directory.
Gets the full path to the designated save directory. This can be useful if you want to use the standard io library (or something else) to read or write in the save directory.
Gets the global scale factor for doppler effects.
Gets the hardware scancode corresponding to the given key.
Gets the height in pixels of the window.
Gets the height of a specific sub-string that was previously added to the Text object.
Gets the height of the ImageData in pixels.
Gets the height of the ImageData in pixels.
Gets the height of the Canvas.
Gets the height of the CompressedImageData.
Gets the height of the Font in pixels.
Gets the height of the Font. The height of the font is the size including any spacing; the height which it will need.
Gets the height of the Image.
Gets the height of the Video in pixels.
Gets the height of the Video.
Gets the height of the text in pixels.
Gets the height of the text.
Gets the height of the window.
Gets the highest allowed force.
Gets the image used for the particles.
Gets the joint limits.
Gets the joystick's unique identifier.

Gets the joystick's unique identifier. The identifier will remain the same for the life of the game, even when the Joystick is disconnected and reconnected, but it will change when the game is re-launched.
Gets the key corresponding to the given hardware scancode.
Gets the last modification time of a file.
Gets the lifetime of the particles.
Gets the line height.
Gets the line height. This will be the value previously set by Font:setLineHeight, or 1.0 by default.
Gets the line join style.
Gets the line style.
Gets the linear acceleration (acceleration along the x and y axes) for particles.
Gets the linear damping of the Body.
Gets the linear velocity of the Body from its center of mass.
Gets the lower limit.
Gets the max supported point size.
Gets the max supported width or height of Images and Canvases.
Gets the max supported width or height of Images and Canvases.
Gets the maximum friction force in Newtons.
Gets the maximum friction torque in Newton-meters.
Gets the maximum length of a RopeJoint.
Gets the maximum motor force.
Gets the maximum number of particles the ParticleSystem can have at once.
Gets the maximum number of sprites the SpriteBatch can hold.
Gets the mipmap filter mode for an Image.
Gets the mode used when drawing the Mesh.
Gets the mode used when the ParticleSystem adds new particles.
Gets the motor speed.
Gets the name of a display.
Gets the name of the joystick.
Gets the number of mipmap levels in the CompressedImageData. The base mipmap level (original image) is included in the count.
Gets the number of CPU cores in the system.
Gets the number of FSAA samples used when drawing to the Canvas.
Gets the number of MSAA samples used when drawing to the Canvas.
Gets the number of antialiasing samples used when drawing to the Canvas.
Gets the number of axes on the joystick.
Gets the number of buttons on the joystick.
Gets the number of channels in the Source.
Gets the number of channels in the Source. Only 1-channel (mono) Sources can use directional and positional effects.
Gets the number of connected joysticks.
Gets the number of connected monitors.
Gets the number of hats on the joystick.
Gets the number of mipmap levels in the CompressedImageData.
Gets the number of multisample antialiasing (MSAA) samples used when drawing to the Canvas.
Gets the number of particles that are currently in the system.
Gets the number of sprites currently in the SpriteBatch.
Gets the optional graphics features and whether they're supported on the system.
Gets the optional graphics features and whether they're supported.
Gets the original ImageData or CompressedData used to create the Image.
Gets the particle image's draw offset.
Gets the pixel at the specified position from a Canvas.
Gets the pixel at the specified position in a Canvas.
Gets the platform-specific absolute path of the directory containing a filepath.
Gets the position of the Source.
Gets the position of the emitter.
Gets the position of the window on the screen.
Gets the properties of a specific attribute within a vertex in the Mesh.
Gets the properties of a vertex in the Mesh.
Gets the radial acceleration (away from the emitter).
Gets the radius of the circle shape.
Gets the radius of the shape.
Gets the range of vertices used when drawing the Mesh.
Gets the reference and maximum attenuation distances of the Source.
Gets the reference and maximum attenuation distances of the Source. The values, combined with the current DistanceModel, affect how the Source's volume attenuates based on distance from the listener.
Gets the response speed.
Gets the restitution of this shape.
Gets the rotation of the image upon particle creation (in radians).
Gets the rotational inertia of the body.
Gets the sample at the specified position.
Gets the scaling filters used when drawing the Video.
Gets the seed of the random number generator object.
Gets the seed of the random number generator.
Gets the series of colors applied to the particle sprite.
Gets the series of sizes by which the sprite is scaled. 1.0 is normal size. The particle system will interpolate between each size evenly over the particle's lifetime.
Gets the size in bytes of a file.
Gets the sizes of the particle over its lifetime.
Gets the sleep behaviour of the world.
Gets the speed of the particles.
Gets the spin of the sprite.
Gets the system-dependent maximum value for a love.graphics feature.
Gets the system-dependent maximum values for love.graphics features.
Gets the tangential acceleration (acceleration perpendicular to the particle's direction).
Gets the target angular offset between the two Bodies the Joint is attached to.
Gets the target linear offset between the two Bodies the Joint is attached to.
Gets the target point.
Gets the texture (Image or Canvas) used by the SpriteBatch.
Gets the texture (Image or Canvas) used for the particles.
Gets the texture (Image or Canvas) used when drawing the Mesh.
Gets the texture format of the Canvas.
Gets the total number of vertices in the Mesh.
Gets the two Fixtures that hold the shapes that are in contact.
Gets the type (static or stream) of the Source.
Gets the type of the Cursor.
Gets the type of the object as a string.
Gets the upper limit.
Gets the velocity of the Source.
Gets the vertex components of a Mesh that wasn't created with a custom vertex format.
Gets the vertex format that the Mesh was created with.
Gets the vertex map for the Mesh.

Gets the vertex map for the Mesh. The vertex map describes the order in which the vertices are used when the Mesh is drawn. The vertices, vertex map, and mesh draw mode work together to determine what exactly is displayed on the screen.
Gets the vertex that establishes a connection to the next shape.
Gets the vertex that establishes a connection to the previous shape.
Gets the width and height in pixels of the window.
Gets the width and height of a specific sub-string that was previously added to the Text object.
Gets the width and height of the CompressedImageData.
Gets the width and height of the ImageData in pixels.
Gets the width and height of the ImageData in pixels.
Gets the width and height of the Canvas.
Gets the width and height of the CompressedImageData.
Gets the width and height of the Image.
Gets the width and height of the Video in pixels.
Gets the width and height of the Video.
Gets the width and height of the desktop.
Gets the width and height of the text in pixels.
Gets the width and height of the text.
Gets the width and height of the window.
Gets the width in pixels of the window.
Gets the width of a specific sub-string that was previously added to the Text object.
Gets the width of the ImageData in pixels.
Gets the width of the ImageData in pixels.
Gets the width of the Canvas.
Gets the width of the CompressedImageData.
Gets the width of the Image.
Gets the width of the Video in pixels.
Gets the width of the Video.
Gets the width of the text in pixels.
Gets the width of the text.
Gets the width of the window.
Gets the window caption.
Gets the window icon.
Gets the window title.
Gets the world-space axis vector of the Prismatic Joint.
Gets the world-space axis vector of the Wheel Joint.
Gets the wrapping properties of a Canvas.
Gets the wrapping properties of a Framebuffer.
Gets the wrapping properties of an Image.
Gets the write directory name for your game.
Gets the write directory name for your game. Note that this only returns the name of the folder to store your files in, not the full path.
Gets the x-coordinate of the particle emitter's position.
Gets the y-coordinate of the particle emitter's position.
Gets warning and error messages (if any).
Gets warning messages (if any).
Gets whether text input events are enabled.
Gets whether a filepath is actually a symbolic link.
Gets whether a specific vertex attribute in the Mesh is enabled.
Gets whether a specific vertex attribute in the Mesh is enabled. Vertex data from disabled attributes is not used when drawing the Mesh.
Gets whether cursor functionality is supported.
Gets whether end-of-file has been reached.
Gets whether gamma-correct rendering is enabled.
Gets whether gamma-correct rendering is supported and enabled. It can be enabled by setting t.gammacorrect = true in love.conf.
Gets whether key repeat is enabled.
Gets whether love.filesystem follows symbolic links.
Gets whether particle angles and rotations are relative to their velocities.
Gets whether particle angles and rotations are relative to their velocities. If enabled, particles are aligned to the angle of their velocities and rotate relative to that angle.
Gets whether per-vertex colors are used instead of the constant color when drawing the Mesh (constant color being love.graphics.setColor.)
Gets whether per-vertex colors are used when drawing the Mesh.
Gets whether relative mode is enabled for the mouse.
Gets whether the Body is destroyed.
Gets whether the Body is destroyed. Destroyed bodies cannot be used.
Gets whether the Fixture is destroyed.
Gets whether the Fixture is destroyed. Destroyed fixtures cannot be used.
Gets whether the Font can render a character or string.
Gets whether the Image was created from CompressedData.
Gets whether the Joint is destroyed.
Gets whether the Joint is destroyed. Destroyed joints cannot be used.
Gets whether the Joystick is connected.
Gets whether the Joystick is recognized as a gamepad.

Gets whether the Joystick is recognized as a gamepad. If this is the case, the Joystick's buttons and axes can be used in a standardized manner across different operating systems and joystick models via Joystick:getGamepadAxis, Joystick:isGamepadDown, love.gamepadpressed, and related functions.
Gets whether the Joystick supports vibration.
Gets whether the Source's position and direction are relative to the listener.
Gets whether the Source's position, velocity, direction, and cone angles are relative to the listener.
Gets whether the Video is currently playing.
Gets whether the Window is currently maximized.
Gets whether the World is destroyed.
Gets whether the World is destroyed. Destroyed worlds cannot be used.
Gets whether the connected Bodies collide.
Gets whether the display is allowed to sleep while the program is running.
Gets whether the file is open.
Gets whether the game is in fused mode or not.
Gets whether the graphics module is able to be used.
Gets whether the graphics module is able to be used. If it is not active, love.graphics function and method calls will not work correctly and may cause the program to crash.
Gets whether the window is fullscreen.
Gets whether wireframe mode is used when drawing.
Gets which categories this shape should NOT collide with.
Gets which categories this shape should NOT collide with. The number of masked categories is the number of return values.
Getting Started
Getting the time of a file and printing it as a date.
Gives control back to the OS for a bit.
Global built-in variables
GlyphData
Grabs the mouse and confines it to the window.
Graphics State
Graphics features that can be checked for with love.graphics.getSupported.
Graphics state stack types used with love.graphics.push.
GraphicsFeature
GraphicsLimit
Grave accent key
Greater-than key
Green component of the clear color (0-255).
Groups, categories, and mask can be used to define the collision behaviour of the fixture.
Guide button.
Hand symbol.
Hangul/English toggle scancode.
Hanja conversion scancode.

Hardware cursors are framerate-independent and work the same way as normal operating system cursors. Unlike drawing an image at the mouse's current coordinates, hardware cursors never have visible lag between when the mouse is moved and when the cursor position updates, even at low framerates.
Hardware setting scancodes
Has been replaced by Fixture:setFriction.
Hash key
Height of the rectangle.
Hello World

Home key
Horizontal wrapping mode of the Canvas.
Horizontal wrapping mode of the Framebuffer.
Horizontal wrapping mode of the framebuffer.
Horizontal wrapping mode of the image.
How a stencil function modifies the stencil values of pixels it touches.
How a Mesh's vertices are used when drawing.
How a Mesh's vertices are used when drawing.
How long the force applies. Usually the inverse time step or 1/dt.
How many bytes have been read
How many bytes to read
How many bytes to write.
How many hats the joystick has
How many hats the joystick has.
How newly created particles are added to the ParticleSystem.
How points should be drawn.
How the image is filtered when scaling.

How the image wraps inside a Quad with a larger quad size than image size. This also affects how Meshes with texture coordinates which are outside the range of [0, 1] are drawn, and the color returned by the TexelShader function when using it to sample from texture coordinates outside of the range of [0, 1].
How the image wraps inside a large Quad.
How the vertices are used when drawing. The default mode "fan" is sufficient for simple convex polygons.
How to decode a given FileData.
How to draw the arc.
How to draw the circle.
How to draw the ellipse.
How to draw the polygon.
How to draw the quad.
How to draw the rectangle.
How to draw the triangle.
How to modify any stencil values of pixels that are touched by what's drawn in the stencil function.
How to scale a font down.
How to scale a font up.
How to scale an image down.
How to scale an image up.
Hyphen-minus key
I has been renamed again.

If love.filesystem.isFused is true, the path returned by this function can be passed to love.filesystem.mount, which will make the directory containing the main game (e.g. C:\Program Files\coolgame\) readable by love.filesystem.
If Relative Mode is enabled for the mouse, the dx and dy arguments of this callback will update but x and y are not guaranteed to.
If t.release is enabled, LÖVE uses the release error handler, which is sparse on information by default, and can, of course, be overridden.

If a Mesh wasn't created with a custom vertex format, it will have 3 vertex attributes named VertexPosition, VertexTexCoord, and VertexColor. If vertex attributes with those names are attached to the SpriteBatch, it will override the SpriteBatch's sprite positions, texture coordinates, and sprite colors, respectively.
If a Mesh with custom vertex attributes is used and one of the attributes is meant to be used as a color in a Shader, and the attribute isn't named "VertexColor".
If a vertex map is used with the Mesh, this method will set a subset of the values in the vertex map array to use, instead of a subset of the total vertices in the Mesh.
If a Shader is used which has uniform / extern variables or other variables that are meant to be used as colors, and Shader:sendColor isn't used.
If a Lua error occurs in the thread, a message with the name "error" gets pushed to its message pool. Retrieve the message with
If a Mesh wasn't created with a custom vertex format, it will have 3 vertex attributes named VertexPosition, VertexTexCoord, and VertexColor.

If a Mesh wasn't created with a custom vertex format, it will have 3 vertex attributes named VertexPosition, VertexTexCoord, and VertexColor. Otherwise the attribute name must either match one of the vertex attributes specified in the vertex format when creating the Mesh, or must match a vertex attribute from another Mesh attached to this Mesh via Mesh:attachAttribute.
If a Mesh wasn't created with a custom vertex format, it will have the following vertex format:

If a custom vertex attribute uses the name "VertexPosition", "VertexTexCoord", or "VertexColor", then the vertex data for that vertex attribute will be used for the standard vertex positions, texture coordinates, or vertex colors respectively, when drawing the Mesh. Otherwise a Vertex Shader is required in order to make use of the vertex attribute when the Mesh is drawn.
If a file called conf.lua is present in your game folder (or .love file), it is run

If a game is in fused mode, its save directory will be directly in the Appdata directory instead of Appdata/LOVE/. The game will also be able to load C Lua dynamic libraries which are located in the save directory.

If fullscreen is enabled and the width or height is not supported (see love.window.getFullscreenModes), the window may be resized to the closest available resolution and a resize event will be triggered.

If fullscreen mode is entered and the window size doesn't match one of the monitor's display modes (in normal fullscreen mode) or the window size doesn't match the desktop size (in 'desktop' fullscreen mode), the window will be resized appropriately. The window will revert back to its original size again when fullscreen mode is exited using this function.
If it isn't supported, calling love.mouse.newCursor and love.mouse.getSystemCursor will cause an error. Mobile devices do not support cursors.

If multiple canvases are being rendered to simultaneously (by giving multiple Canvas parameters to love.graphics.setCanvas), you can use the effects function instead of effect in order to output a separate color to each Canvas. It has the following prototype:
If no color has been set with SpriteBatch:setColor or the current SpriteBatch color has been cleared, this method will return nil.
If no pixel shader is used, LÖVE internally uses a default. This is its code:
If no value is supplied for a specific vertex attribute component, it will be set to a default value of 0 if its data type is "float", or 255 if its data type is "byte".
If no vertex map has been set previously via Mesh:setVertexMap, then this function will return nil in LÖVE 0.10.0+, or an empty table in 0.9.2 and older.
If no vertex shader code is used, LÖVE uses a default. This is its code:

If relative mode is enabled, the cursor is hidden and doesn't move when the mouse does, but relative mouse motion events are still generated via love.mousemoved. This lets the mouse move in any direction indefinitely without the cursor getting stuck at the edges of the screen.
If set to true this allows the user to resize the game's window.
If sleeping is allowed, a body that has come to rest will sleep.
If sleeping is allowed, any body that has come to rest will sleep.
If symbolic links are not enabled (via love.filesystem.setSymlinksEnabled), this function will always return false.
If the Joystick is recognized as a gamepad, the physical locations for the virtual gamepad axes and buttons correspond as closely as possible to the layout of a standard Xbox 360 controller.
If the Joystick only has a single vibration motor, it will still work but it will use the largest value of the left and right parameters.
If the Mesh has a custom vertex map, then that will determine the order in which the vertices are interpreted by the draw mode.
If the Mesh's draw range has not been set previously with Mesh:setDrawRange, this function will return nil.

If the active Canvas has just been changed and the "replace" BlendMode is about to be used to draw something which covers the entire screen, calling love.graphics.discard rather than calling love.graphics.clear or doing nothing may improve performance on mobile devices.
If the body is active or not.
If the c-key is pressed the canvas will be cleared before drawing a new line on the screen.
If the chain should loop back to the first point.
If the end-of-file has been reached
If the file exists in the .love but not in the save directory, it returns false as well.
If the fixture is a sensor.
If the fullscreen type is "desktop", then the window will be automatically resized to the desktop resolution.

If the group and category filtering doesn't generate a collision decision, this function gets called with the two fixtures as arguments. The function should return a boolean value where true means the fixtures will collide and false means they will pass through each other.
If the number of MSAA samples specified is greater than the maximum supported by the system, the Canvas will still be created but only using the maximum supported amount (this includes 0.)
If the operation was successful.
If the path passed to the function exists in the game and the save directory, it will list the files and directories from both places.

If the position to apply the force is not given, it will act on the center of mass of the body. The part of the force not directed towards the center of mass will cause the body to spin (and depends on the rotational inertia).

If the position to apply the impulse is not given, it will act on the center of mass of the body. The part of the impulse not directed towards the center of mass will cause the body to spin (and depends on the rotational inertia).
If this is called it should be before love.graphics.print, Font:getWrap, and other Font methods which use glyph positioning information are called.
If this method is used, it generally shouldn't be called more than once (at most) between love.graphics.draw(mesh, ...) calls.
If this method is used, it generally shouldn't be called more than once (at most) between love.graphics.draw(spritebatch, ...) calls.

If true, mipmaps for the image will be automatically generated (or taken from the images's file if possible, if the image originated from a CompressedImageData). If this value is a table, it should contain a list of other filenames of images of the same format that have progressively half-sized dimensions, all the way down to 1x1. Those images will be used as this Image's mipmap levels.

If two fixtures are in the same group they either always collide if the group is positive, or never collide if it's negative. If the group is zero or they do not match, then the contact filter checks if the fixtures select a category of the other fixture with their masks. The fixtures do not collide if that's not the case. If they do have each other's categories selected, the return value of the custom contact filter will be used. They always collide if none was set.
If width or height is 0, setMode will use the width and height of the desktop.
If width or height is 0, setMode will use the width or height of the desktop.

If you are getting the error message "Could not set write directory", try setting the save directory. This is done either with love.filesystem.setIdentity or by setting the identity field in love.conf (only available with love 0.7 or higher).

If you are getting the error message "Could not set write directory", try setting the save directory. This is done either with love.filesystem.setIdentity or by setting the identity field in love.conf.

If you are just interested to know the position on the curve given a parameter, use BezierCurve:evaluate.
If you are just need to know the position on the curve given a parameter, use BezierCurve:evaluate.
If you are just trying to make a character jump around on blocks or the likes, then move along, nothing to see here.
If you don't need the physics module or joystick module, do the following.

If you feel that finding the correct mass properties is tricky, then this function may be able to help you. After creating the needed shapes on the Body, a call to this function will set the mass properties based on those shapes. Remember to call this function after adding the shapes.

If you have disabled the screen in conf.lua and use this function to manually create the window, then you must not call any other love.graphics.* function before this one. Doing so will result in undefined behavior and/or crashes.

If you have disabled the window in conf.lua (i.e. t.window = false) and use this function to manually create the window, then you must not call any other love.graphics.* function before this one. Doing so will result in undefined behavior and/or crashes because OpenGL cannot function properly without a window.

In both cases, love.math.gammaToLinear can be used to convert color values to linear RGB in Lua code, or the gammaCorrectColor (or unGammaCorrectColor if necessary) shader functions can be used inside shader code. Those shader functions
In exclusive fullscreen mode, if a window size is used which does not match one of the monitor's supported display modes, the window will be resized to the next largest display mode.
In general, rgba8, rgba4, and rgb5a1 are supported everywhere. rgb10a2 is also supported everywhere on desktop platforms.
In general, colors chosen based on what they look like on-screen are already in gamma-space and should not be double-converted. Colors calculated using math are often in the linear RGB space.
In many cases, you draw images or shapes in terms of their upper-left corner (See the picture above).
In the context of love threads, a flat table is understood to not contain tables, functions, userData or a metatable.

In version 0.8.0 and older, love.graphics.print stops at the first '\0' (null) character. This can bite you if you are appending keystrokes to form your string, as some of those are multi-byte unicode characters which will likely contain null bytes.
In version 0.9.2, a bug caused this function to reset all transformations. It was fixed in 0.10.0. A workaround for 0.9.2 would be to use a combination of rotating and scaling to imitate shearing.
In version 0.9.2 and earlier this is represented by the actual space character ' '.

In version 0.9.2 and earlier, wrapping was implemented by breaking up words by spaces and putting them back together to make sure things fit nicely within the limit provided. However, due to the way this is done, extra spaces between words would end up missing when printed on the screen, and some lines could overflow past the provided wrap limit. In version 0.10.0 and newer this is no longer the case.
In version 0.9.2 and older, the global color set with love.graphics.setColor will not work on the SpriteBatch if any of the sprites has its own color.
In versions prior to 0.10.0 it was named CompressedData, however that name is used for something else now.
In versions prior to 0.10.0 it's best to call this method directly after creating the image with love.graphics.newImage, to avoid bugs in certain graphics drivers.
In versions prior to 0.10.0 the CompressedData name was used for CompressedImageData objects.

In versions prior to 0.10.0 the width of the separator area after a particular font glyph sets the amount of space that goes after the glyph. As of 0.10.0, it is possible to add negative spacing for all characters by using the 3-parameter version of love.graphics.newImageFont and giving a negative number as the third parameter.

In versions prior to 0.10.0, calling this function automatically creates mipmaps for the Image if none exist yet. If the image is compressed and its CompressedData has mipmap data included, it will use that.
In versions prior to 0.10.0, not all graphics cards that LÖVE supported could use Canvases. love.graphics.isSupported("canvas") could be used to check for support at runtime.
In versions prior to 0.9.0, LÖVE expects ISO 8859-1 encoding for the glyphs string.

It is changed in World:update by applying torques, off centre forces/impulses, and angular damping. It can be set directly with Body:setAngularVelocity.

It is important to note that love.filesystem.load does not invoke the code, it just creates a function (a 'chunk') that will contain the contents of the file inside it. In order to execute the chunk, you have to put () behind it.
It is possible to cause a collision with another body by changing its angle.

It is possible to defer window creation until love.window.setMode is first called in your code. To do so, set t.window = nil in love.conf (or t.screen = nil in older versions.) If this is done, LÖVE may crash if any function from love.graphics is called before the first love.window.setMode in your code.
It is possible to define new events by appending the table love.handlers. Such functions can be invoked as usual, via love.event.push using the table index as an argument.
It is possible to draw to the screen and to the stencil values of pixels at the same time, by using love.graphics.setColorMask inside the stencil function to enable drawing to all color components.
It is possible to have more areas in the image than are required for the font in the love.graphics.newImageFont() call. The extra areas are ignored.
It is recommended to create shapes no larger than 10 times the scale. This is important because Box2D is tuned to work well with shape sizes from 0.1 to 10 meters.
It is recommended to create shapes no larger than 10 times the scale. This is important because Box2D is tuned to work well with shape sizes from 0.1 to 10 meters. The default meter scale is 30.
It is recommended to set your game's identity first in your conf.lua. You can set it with love.filesystem.setIdentity as well.

It provides all its functions inside the table returned by require("utf8"). This library does not provide any support for Unicode other than handling UTF-8 encoding. Any operation that needs the meaning of a character, such as character classification, is outside its scope.

It's possible to rotate an object about its center by offsetting the origin to the center. Angles must be given in radians for rotation. One can also use a negative scaling factor to flip about its centerline.
It's recommended that Font objects are created with love.graphics.newFont in the loading stage and then passed to this function in the drawing stage.

It's safe to assume the maximum texture size will never be less than 1024 and will almost always be 2048 or greater.There is an online database which has collected info about the max texture size for various systems.

LÖVE
LÖVE 0.9.0 had a bug which required the button indices passed to Joystick:isDown to be 0-based instead of 1-based, for example button 1 would be 0 for this function. It was fixed in 0.9.1.
LÖVE adds two loaders (before the Lua loaders) that search for modules in the game and save directory. These loaders are not affected by Lua's package.path.
LÖVE automatically recognizes most popular controllers with a similar layout to the Xbox 360 controller as gamepads, but you can add more with love.joystick.setGamepadMapping.
LÖVE includes built-in gamepad bindings for many common controllers. This function lets you change the bindings or add new ones for types of Joysticks which aren't recognized as gamepads by default.
LÖVE provides default placeholders for these callbacks, which you can override inside your own code by creating your own function with the same name as the callback:
LÖVE provides several built-in variables for both pixel and vertex shaders. The full list can be found here: Shader Variables.
LÖVE shader language

LÖVE's coordinate system is rooted in the upper-left corner of the screen, which is at location (0, 0). The x axis is horizontal: larger values are further to the right. The y axis is vertical: larger values are further towards the bottom.

Mipmap filtering cannot be activated for an Image created from a CompressedImageData which does not have enough mipmap levels to go down to 1x1. For example, a 256x256 image created from a CompressedImageData should have 8 mipmap levels or Image:setMipmapFilter will error. Most tools which can create compressed textures are able to automatically generate mipmaps for them in the same file.
Misc.
Miscellaneous keys

Mobile operating systems may forcefully kill the game if it uses too much memory, so any non-critical resource should be removed if possible (by setting all variables referencing the resources to nil, and calling collectgarbage()), when this event is triggered. Sounds and images in particular tend to use the most memory.

Nil is the type of the value nil, whose main property is to be different from any other value; it usually represents the absence of a useful value.

Normally it isn't necessary to call this method as love.graphics.draw(mesh, ...) will do it automatically if needed, but explicitly using Mesh:flush gives more control over when the work happens.

Normally it isn't necessary to call this method as love.graphics.draw(spritebatch, ...) will do it automatically if needed, but explicitly using SpriteBatch:flush gives more control over when the work happens.
Normally the same thing will be drawn on each canvas, but that can be changed if a pixel shader is used with the effects function instead of the regular effect.
Not all cursor types are available on all operating systems. If an unsupported type is used, it will default to something else.

Not all devices support gamma-correct rendering, in which case it will be automatically disabled and this function will return false. It is supported on desktop systems which have graphics cards that are capable of using OpenGL 3 / DirectX 10, and iOS devices that can use OpenGL ES 3.
Not all formats are supported in love.graphics Images on all systems, although the DXT formats have close to 100% support on desktop operating systems.
Not all systems support every format. Use love.graphics.getCanvasFormats to check before creating the Canvas.
Not all systems support the HDR and sRGB formats. Use love.graphics.isSupported to check before creating the Canvas or Image.
Not plugged in, running on a battery.
Not stable in 0.8.0. You may experience crashing.
Note
Note how love.keypressed gives direct key presses, whereas love.textinput gives the text that key combinations produce.
Note that Box2D doesn't allow destroying or creating shapes during collision callbacks.
Note that static bodies (with zero mass) always use CCD, so your walls will not let a fast moving body pass through even if it is not a bullet.
Note that the scissor area bounds the cleared region.
Note that the Shape object is copied rather than kept as a reference when the Fixture is created. To get the Shape object that the Fixture owns, use Fixture:getShape.
Note that the body's coordinates in meters remain unchanged
Note that the force components and position must be given in world coordinates.
Note that the impulse components and position must be given in world coordinates.
Note that the limit argument affects the position of your text for 'center' and 'right' alignment.
Note that the offsets are applied before rotation, scaling, or shearing; scaling and shearing are applied before rotation.
Note that this function just replaces the contents in the destination rectangle; it does not do any alpha blending.
Note that this may not be the center of mass of the body.
Note that you can't disable love.filesystem; it's mandatory. The same goes for the love module itself. love.graphics needs love.window to be enabled.
Note(s)
Note: All paths are relative to the .love archive and save directory. (except for the get*Directory() calls)

Note: The math for this blend mode is not completely correct when using the "alphamultiply" alpha mode. Prefer the "premultiplied" variant (and be sure your content has its RGB multiplied by its alpha at some point before blending), when possible.
Notes
Nothing
Nothing yet.
